skill.name: detection-sigma
skill.description: Generic detection rule creation and management using Sigma, the universal SIEM rule format. Sigma provides vendor-agnostic detection logic for log analysis across multiple SIEM platforms. Use when: (1) Creating detection rules for security monitoring, (2) Converting rules between SIEM platforms (Splunk, Elastic, QRadar, Sentinel), (3) Threat hunting with standardized detection patterns, (4) Building detection-as-code pipelines, (5) Mapping detections to MITRE ATT&CK tactics, (6) Implementing compliance-based monitoring rules.
skill.summary: Generic detection rule creation and management using Sigma, the universal SIEM rule format. Sigma pr...
skill.author: AgentSecOps

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing YAML templates and reference guides for defensive security detection engineering. All static findings are FALSE POSITIVES - the flagged patterns are detection rules designed to identify malicious activity, not perform it. This skill does not contain executable code, network access, or file system operations. Previous Claude audit correctly identified this as safe.

content.user_title: Create Sigma Detection Rules for SIEM
content.value_statement: Security teams need vendor-agnostic detection rules that work across multiple SIEM platforms. This skill provides templates, workflows, and references for creating, validating, and converting Sigma rules to Splunk, Elastic, Sentinel, QRadar, and other platforms.
actual_capabilities: Create detection rules using Sigma YAML format with field modifiers
Convert rules to 25+ SIEM backends including Splunk, Elastic, Sentinel, QRadar
Map detections to MITRE ATT&CK tactics and techniques
Build compliance-based monitoring rules for PCI-DSS, NIST, ISO 27001
Use pre-built templates for credential access, persistence, lateral movement
Validate rule syntax and test against sample log data
limitations: Requires Python pysigma library for rule conversion (not included)
Does not execute or deploy rules to SIEM platforms directly
Actual detection requires log sources to be ingested in target SIEM
Backend compatibility varies by modifier type

use_cases.title: Build Detection Rules
use_cases.description: Create detection rules for security monitoring based on threat intelligence and attack patterns.

use_cases.title: Migrate SIEM Rules
use_cases.description: Convert existing detection rules between SIEM platforms or build new rules from Sigma specification.

use_cases.title: Compliance Monitoring
use_cases.description: Implement detection rules for PCI-DSS, NIST 800-53, and ISO 27001 audit requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Detection Rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Sigma detection rule for [process_name] with suspicious [indicators] in [log_source]. Include MITRE ATT&CK mapping.

prompt_templates.title: SIEM Conversion
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this Sigma rule to [Splunk|Elasticsearch|Sentinel|QRadar] format. Show the converted query and field mappings.

prompt_templates.title: MITRE Mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Create Sigma detection rules for MITRE ATT&CK technique [T####.###] covering [tactic_name]. Include log sources and key fields.

prompt_templates.title: Compliance Rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create Sigma detection rules for [PCI-DSS|NIST|ISO27001] requirement [control_id]. Include tags and documentation.

output_examples.input: Create a Sigma rule to detect PowerShell encoded commands
output: Log Source: Windows process_creation (Sysmon Event ID 1)
Detection: Image endswith powershell.exe AND CommandLine contains -enc or FromBase64String
Supported backends: Splunk SPL, Elastic Query DSL, Sentinel KQL, QRadar AQL
Severity: Medium with false positive notes for admin scripts

output_examples.input: Convert this rule to Splunk format
output: Original Sigma: Detects credential dumping via lsass.exe memory access
Splunk SPL: index=windows EventID=4656 Image=*\lsass.exe GrantedAccess IN (0x1010, 0x1410)
Field mappings verified for Sysmon Event ID 10
Detection ready for Splunk Enterprise Security
ISO 27001 A.12.4.1: User activity monitoring rule created
Admin activity detection for admin, Administrator, root accounts
Rule tagged: iso27001.a.12.4.1 for compliance evidence

best_practices: Use specific field modifiers like endswith instead of contains for better performance
Start rules at experimental status and promote after testing in non-production
Tag all rules with MITRE ATT&CK techniques and compliance framework controls
anti_patterns: Using overly broad detection criteria that generates excessive false positives
Deploying rules without testing against historical log data first
Creating rules without documenting false positive scenarios and mitigation filters

faq.question: What SIEM platforms does Sigma support?
faq.answer: Sigma converts to 25+ platforms including Splunk, Elastic, QRadar, Microsoft Sentinel, Chronicle, LogPoint, ArcSight, and EDR platforms.

faq.question: What Python packages are required?
faq.answer: Install pysigma plus backend plugins: pip install pysigma pysigma-backend-splunk pysigma-backend-elasticsearch pyyaml.

faq.question: Can I use this with existing Sigma rules?
faq.answer: Yes. Import rules from SigmaHQ repository or use the skill to convert, validate, and customize existing rules for your environment.

faq.question: How is sensitive data handled?
faq.answer: Sigma rules reference field names and patterns. Never include actual sensitive data in rule values. Store rules with version control access controls.

faq.question: Why is my converted query not working in SIEM?
faq.answer: Verify log source availability, check field name mappings, test time range, and ensure backend supports all modifiers used in the rule.

faq.question: How does this differ from writing SIEM queries directly?
faq.answer: Sigma rules are vendor-agnostic. Write once and convert to any supported backend, enabling portability across SIEM platforms and detection-as-code workflows.
